        <div class="product-page-header__notes typography-caption">
            <div class="truncated-content-in-modal">
<!---->
    <div class="truncated-content-container" style="height: undefined">
        <span class="line-clamp " data-clamp>
    <p dir="false" data-test-bidi><span
                    data-test-truncated-content-inline-title
                    class="truncated-content-in-modal__inline-title"
                >Editors’ Notes</span>
                <i>2wice</i> marks Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs’ first offering since being acquitted of sexual assault in 2016—a charge that could’ve landed him in jail for 10 years. The material here is accordingly reflective, tempering Gibbs’ street operas with musings on potential (“Crushed Glass”), parenting (“Homesick”), and growing up (“Alexys”). As always, Gibbs’ raps are low-key but expertly constructed, the work of a guy confident enough to know he doesn’t need to show off.</p>
</span>

<!---->    </div>
</div>


        </div>
</div>

                    <span>
                        TIME
                    </span>

unlikely. The former is the ultimate crate-digger, known as much for his reclusive tendencies as his endless collection of obscure soul, jazz, rock, and other musical ephemera; the latter is a street-hardened former dealer who rhymes about the perils of the dope game. But they say opposites attract, and in this case their two aesthetics complement one another. Gibbs is a nimble, gifted rapper, his syllables quick-stepping around Madlib's many twists and turns, from the grainy '70s soul-funk of \\\"Scarface\\\" to the half-time disco of \\\"Harold's\\\" to the hazy West Coast G-funk of \\\"Thuggin.\\\" The duo's credentials are strong enough to pull some of hip-hop's finest into their orbit: oddball Danny Brown contributes a verse to the squirming \\\"High,\\\" while the crews from The Wu-Tang Clan, Top Dog Entertainment, and Odd Future are all represented (via cameos from Raekwon, Ab Soul, and Earl Sweatshirt, respectively). with \u003ci\u003eFull Metal Jackit\u003c/i\u003e, the first of many mixtapes. Two years later he scored a deal with Interscope, but was dropped before his album was released. Undaunted, he continued to record independently and flood the streets with a gang of new material, most notably \u003ci\u003eThe Miseducation of Freddie Gibbs\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003emidwestgangstaboxframecadillacmuzik\u003c/i\u003e. Over the last few years, he's collaborated with artists from commercial staples like Young Jeezy and DJ Drama to underground icons Madlib and Statik Selektah. And his reputation has kept growing. With a gruff yet smooth flow and vivid storytelling verses, he rhymes mostly about various hood scenarios, sharing mic time with guests like Z-Ro, Curren$y, Krayzie Bone, Jadakiss, Dom Kennedy, SpaceGistPurp, and more. While this isn't his greatest album, there's no shortage of epic music. Don't miss \\\"On Me,\\\" \\\"Breaking Bad,\\\" or the femme-fatale anthem \\\"Walk in Wit the         <div class="product-page-header__notes typography-caption">
            <div class="truncated-content-in-modal">
<!---->
    <div class="truncated-content-container" style="height: undefined">
        <span class="line-clamp " data-clamp>
    <p dir="false" data-test-bidi><span
                    data-test-truncated-content-inline-title
                    class="truncated-content-in-modal__inline-title"
                >Editors’ Notes</span>
                <i>2wice</i> marks Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs’ first offering since being acquitted of sexual assault in 2016—a charge that could’ve landed him in jail for 10 years. The material here is accordingly reflective, tempering Gibbs’ street operas with musings on potential (“Crushed Glass”), parenting (“Homesick”), and growing up (“Alexys”). As always, Gibbs’ raps are low-key but expertly constructed, the work of a guy confident enough to know he doesn’t need to show off.</p>
</span>

<!---->    </div>
</div>


        </div>
</div>

                        TIME

2014 Madlib Invazion\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"826080165\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"At first glance, the pairing of producer Madlib and rapper Freddie Gibbs seems unlikely. The former is the ultimate crate-digger, known as much for his reclusive tendencies as his endless collection of obscure soul, jazz, rock, and other musical ephemera; the latter is a street-hardened former dealer who rhymes about the perils of the dope game. But they say opposites attract, and in this case their two aesthetics complement one another. Gibbs is a nimble, gifted rapper, his syllables quick-stepping around Madlib's many twists and turns, from the grainy '70s soul-funk of \\\"Scarface\\\" to the half-time disco of \\\"Harold's\\\" to the hazy West Coast G-funk of \\\"Thuggin.\\\" The duo's credentials are strong enough to pull some of hip-hop's finest into their orbit: oddball Danny Brown contributes a verse to the squirming \\\"High,\\\" while the crews from The Wu-Tang Clan, Top Dog Entertainment, and Odd Future are all represented (via cameos from Raekwon, Ab Soul, and Earl Sweatshirt, respectively). As a final shot of gravitas, Scarface drops a verse on \\\"Broken.\\\" It's a deserved blessing from one of hip-hop's finest MCs to one of its most unlikely but successful If 2014’s \u003ci\u003ePiñata\u003c/i\u003e proved that the pairing—offbeat producer, no-frills street rapper—sounded better and more natural than it looked on paper, \u003ci\u003eBandana\u003c/i\u003e proves \u003ci\u003ePiñata\u003c/i\u003e wasn’t a fluke. The common ground is approachability: Even at their most cinematic (the noisy soul of “Flat Tummy Tea,” the horror-movie trap of “Half Manne Half Cocaine”), Madlib’s beats remain funny, strange, decidedly at human scale, while Gibbs prefers to keep things so real he barely uses metaphor. wary of talking himself up—he’s more show than tell. But between 2019’s Madlib collaboration (\u003ci\u003eBandana\u003c/i\u003e) and the Alchemist-led \u003ci\u003eAlfredo\u003c/i\u003e, what wasn’t clear 10 years ago is crystal now: Gibbs is in his own class. The wild, shape-shifting flow of “God Is Perfect,” the chilling lament of “Skinny Suge” (“Man, my uncle died off a overdose/And the fucked-up part of that is I know I supplied the n***a that sold it”), a mind that flickers with street violence and half-remembered Arabic, and beats that don’t bang so much as twinkle, glide, and go up like smoke. \u003ci\u003eAlfredo\u003c/i\u003e is seamless, seductive, but effortless, the work of two guys who don’t run to catch planes. On “Something to Rap About,” Gibbs claims, “God made me sell crack so I had something to rap about.” But the way he flows now, you get the sense he would’ve found his way to the mic one way or the Two years later he scored a deal with Interscope, but was dropped before his album was released. Undaunted, he continued to record independently and flood the streets with a gang of new material, most notably \u003ci\u003eThe Miseducation of Freddie Gibbs\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003emidwestgangstaboxframecadillacmuzik\u003c/i\u003e. Over the last few years, he's collaborated with artists from commercial staples like Young Jeezy and DJ Drama to underground icons Madlib and Statik Selektah. And his reputation has kept growing. With a gruff yet smooth flow and vivid storytelling verses, he rhymes mostly about various hood scenarios, sharing mic time with guests like Z-Ro, Curren$y, Krayzie Bone, Jadakiss, Dom Kennedy, SpaceGistPurp, and more. While this isn't his greatest album, there's no shortage of epic music. Juicy J (\\\"Str8 Slammin'\\\"), as well as more obscure cats like B.J. the Chicago Kid, Alley Boy, and Polyester. The production is fantastic and surprisingly varied, with tons of soulful samples and more straightforward synth bangers. Vocally, Gibbs combines the raspiness of a young Ja Rule crossed with the deep thinking of Scarface or Big K.R.I.T.         <div class="product-page-header__notes typography-caption">
            <div class="truncated-content-in-modal">
<!---->
    <div class="truncated-content-container" style="height: undefined">
        <span class="line-clamp " data-clamp>
    <p dir="false" data-test-bidi><span
                    data-test-truncated-content-inline-title
                    class="truncated-content-in-modal__inline-title"
                >Editors’ Notes</span>
                <i>2wice</i> marks Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs’ first offering since being acquitted of sexual assault in 2016—a charge that could’ve landed him in jail for 10 years. The material here is accordingly reflective, tempering Gibbs’ street operas with musings on potential (“Crushed Glass”), parenting (“Homesick”), and growing up (“Alexys”). As always, Gibbs’ raps are low-key but expertly constructed, the work of a guy confident enough to know he doesn’t need to show off.</p>
</span>

<!---->    </div>
</div>


        </div>
</div>

                        TIME

unlikely. The former is the ultimate crate-digger, known as much for his reclusive tendencies as his endless collection of obscure soul, jazz, rock, and other musical ephemera; the latter is a street-hardened former dealer who rhymes about the perils of the dope game. But they say opposites attract, and in this case their two aesthetics complement one another. Gibbs is a nimble, gifted rapper, his syllables quick-stepping around Madlib's many twists and turns, from the grainy '70s soul-funk of \\\"Scarface\\\" to the half-time disco of \\\"Harold's\\\" to the hazy West Coast G-funk of \\\"Thuggin.\\\" The duo's credentials are strong enough to pull some of hip-hop's finest into their orbit: oddball Danny Brown contributes a verse to the squirming \\\"High,\\\" while the crews from The Wu-Tang Clan, Top Dog Entertainment, and Odd Future are all represented (via cameos from Raekwon, Ab Soul, and Earl Sweatshirt, respectively). As a final shot of gravitas, Scarface drops a verse on \\\"Broken.\\\" It's a deserved blessing from one of hip-hop's finest MCs to one of its most unlikely but successful If 2014’s \u003ci\u003ePiñata\u003c/i\u003e proved that the pairing—offbeat producer, no-frills street rapper—sounded better and more natural than it looked on paper, \u003ci\u003eBandana\u003c/i\u003e proves \u003ci\u003ePiñata\u003c/i\u003e wasn’t a fluke. The common ground is approachability: Even at their most cinematic (the noisy soul of “Flat Tummy Tea,” the horror-movie trap of “Half Manne Half Cocaine”), Madlib’s beats remain funny, strange, decidedly at human scale, while Gibbs prefers to keep things so real he barely uses metaphor. On \u003ci\u003eCold Day in Hell\u003c/i\u003e, he joins forces with a diverse crew of fellow emcees, including big names like Young Jeezy (\\\"Twos and Fews\\\"), 2 Chainz (\\\"Neighborhood Hoez\\\"), and Memphis O.G. Juicy J (\\\"Str8 Slammin'\\\"), as well as more obscure cats like B.J. the Chicago Kid, Alley Boy, and Polyester. The production is fantastic and surprisingly varied, with tons of soulful samples and more straightforward synth bangers. Vocally, Gibbs combines the raspiness of a young Ja Rule crossed with the deep thinking of Scarface or Big K.R.I.T.         <div class="product-page-header__notes typography-caption">
            <div class="truncated-content-in-modal">
<!---->
    <div class="truncated-content-container" style="height: undefined">
        <span class="line-clamp " data-clamp>
    <p dir="false" data-test-bidi><span
                    data-test-truncated-content-inline-title
                    class="truncated-content-in-modal__inline-title"
                >Editors’ Notes</span>
                <i>2wice</i> marks Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs’ first offering since being acquitted of sexual assault in 2016—a charge that could’ve landed him in jail for 10 years. The material here is accordingly reflective, tempering Gibbs’ street operas with musings on potential (“Crushed Glass”), parenting (“Homesick”), and growing up (“Alexys”). As always, Gibbs’ raps are low-key but expertly constructed, the work of a guy confident enough to know he doesn’t need to show off.</p>
</span>

<!---->    </div>
</div>


        </div>
</div>

                        TIME

The former is the ultimate crate-digger, known as much for his reclusive tendencies as his endless collection of obscure soul, jazz, rock, and other musical ephemera; the latter is a street-hardened former dealer who rhymes about the perils of the dope game. But they say opposites attract, and in this case their two aesthetics complement one another. Gibbs is a nimble, gifted rapper, his syllables quick-stepping around Madlib's many twists and turns, from the grainy '70s soul-funk of \\\"Scarface\\\" to the half-time disco of \\\"Harold's\\\" to the hazy West Coast G-funk of \\\"Thuggin.\\\" The duo's credentials are strong enough to pull some of hip-hop's finest into their orbit: oddball Danny Brown contributes a verse to the squirming \\\"High,\\\" while the crews from The Wu-Tang Clan, Top Dog Entertainment, and Odd Future are all represented (via cameos from Raekwon, Ab Soul, and Earl Sweatshirt, respectively). As a final shot of gravitas, Scarface drops a verse on \\\"Broken.\\\" It's a deserved blessing from one of hip-hop's finest MCs to one of its most unlikely but successful Rocking a compelling mix of thugged-out street tales and sensitive/intellectual musings, he was briefly signed to Interscope and has since dropped a gang of impressive mixtapes (such as \u003ci\u003eThe Miseducation of Freddie Gibbs\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003eFull Metal Jackit\u003c/i\u003e). He's also collaborated on EPs with Madlib and Statik Selektah; another one with Ski Beatz is in the works. On \u003ci\u003eCold Day in Hell\u003c/i\u003e, he joins forces with a diverse crew of fellow emcees, including big names like Young Jeezy (\\\"Twos and Fews\\\"), 2 Chainz (\\\"Neighborhood Hoez\\\"), and Memphis O.G. Juicy J (\\\"Str8 Slammin'\\\"), as well as more obscure cats like B.J. the Chicago Kid, Alley Boy, and Polyester. The production is fantastic and surprisingly varied, with tons of soulful samples and more straightforward synth bangers. Vocally, Gibbs combines the raspiness of a young Ja Rule crossed with the deep thinking of Scarface or Big K.R.I.T.         <div class="product-page-header__notes typography-caption">
            <div class="truncated-content-in-modal">
<!---->
    <div class="truncated-content-container" style="height: undefined">
        <span class="line-clamp " data-clamp>
    <p dir="false" data-test-bidi><span
                    data-test-truncated-content-inline-title
                    class="truncated-content-in-modal__inline-title"
                >Editors’ Notes</span>
                <i>2wice</i> marks Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs’ first offering since being acquitted of sexual assault in 2016—a charge that could’ve landed him in jail for 10 years. The material here is accordingly reflective, tempering Gibbs’ street operas with musings on potential (“Crushed Glass”), parenting (“Homesick”), and growing up (“Alexys”). As always, Gibbs’ raps are low-key but expertly constructed, the work of a guy confident enough to know he doesn’t need to show off.</p>
</span>

<!---->    </div>
</div>


        </div>
</div>

                    <span>
                        TIME
                    </span>

2014 Madlib Invazion\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"826080165\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"At first glance, the pairing of producer Madlib and rapper Freddie Gibbs seems unlikely. The former is the ultimate crate-digger, known as much for his reclusive tendencies as his endless collection of obscure soul, jazz, rock, and other musical ephemera; the latter is a street-hardened former dealer who rhymes about the perils of the dope game. But they say opposites attract, and in this case their two aesthetics complement one another. Gibbs is a nimble, gifted rapper, his syllables quick-stepping around Madlib's many twists and turns, from the grainy '70s soul-funk of \\\"Scarface\\\" to the half-time disco of \\\"Harold's\\\" to the hazy West Coast G-funk of \\\"Thuggin.\\\" The duo's credentials are strong enough to pull some of hip-hop's finest into their orbit: oddball Danny Brown contributes a verse to the squirming \\\"High,\\\" while the crews from The Wu-Tang Clan, Top Dog Entertainment, and Odd Future are all represented (via cameos from Raekwon, Ab Soul, and Earl Sweatshirt, respectively). As a final shot of gravitas, Scarface drops a verse on \\\"Broken.\\\" It's a deserved blessing from one of hip-hop's finest MCs to one of its most unlikely but successful Rocking a compelling mix of thugged-out street tales and sensitive/intellectual musings, he was briefly signed to Interscope and has since dropped a gang of impressive mixtapes (such as \u003ci\u003eThe Miseducation of Freddie Gibbs\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003eFull Metal Jackit\u003c/i\u003e). He's also collaborated on EPs with Madlib and Statik Selektah; another one with Ski Beatz is in the works. On \u003ci\u003eCold Day in Hell\u003c/i\u003e, he joins forces with a diverse crew of fellow emcees, including big names like Young Jeezy (\\\"Twos and Fews\\\"), 2 Chainz (\\\"Neighborhood Hoez\\\"), and Memphis O.G. Juicy J (\\\"Str8 Slammin'\\\"), as well as more obscure cats like B.J. the Chicago Kid, Alley Boy, and Polyester. The production is fantastic and surprisingly varied, with tons of soulful samples and more straightforward synth bangers. Vocally, Gibbs combines the raspiness of a young Ja Rule crossed with the deep thinking of Scarface or Big K.R.I.T.         <div class="product-page-header__notes typography-caption">
            <div class="truncated-content-in-modal">
<!---->
    <div class="truncated-content-container" style="height: undefined">
        <span class="line-clamp " data-clamp>
    <p dir="false" data-test-bidi><span
                    data-test-truncated-content-inline-title
                    class="truncated-content-in-modal__inline-title"
                >Editors’ Notes</span>
                <i>2wice</i> marks Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs’ first offering since being acquitted of sexual assault in 2016—a charge that could’ve landed him in jail for 10 years. The material here is accordingly reflective, tempering Gibbs’ street operas with musings on potential (“Crushed Glass”), parenting (“Homesick”), and growing up (“Alexys”). As always, Gibbs’ raps are low-key but expertly constructed, the work of a guy confident enough to know he doesn’t need to show off.</p>
</span>

<!---->    </div>
</div>


        </div>
</div>

                        TIME

2014 Madlib Invazion\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"826080165\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"At first glance, the pairing of producer Madlib and rapper Freddie Gibbs seems unlikely. The former is the ultimate crate-digger, known as much for his reclusive tendencies as his endless collection of obscure soul, jazz, rock, and other musical ephemera; the latter is a street-hardened former dealer who rhymes about the perils of the dope game. But they say opposites attract, and in this case their two aesthetics complement one another. Gibbs is a nimble, gifted rapper, his syllables quick-stepping around Madlib's many twists and turns, from the grainy '70s soul-funk of \\\"Scarface\\\" to the half-time disco of \\\"Harold's\\\" to the hazy West Coast G-funk of \\\"Thuggin.\\\" The duo's credentials are strong enough to pull some of hip-hop's finest into their orbit: oddball Danny Brown contributes a verse to the squirming \\\"High,\\\" while the crews from The Wu-Tang Clan, Top Dog Entertainment, and Odd Future are all represented (via cameos from Raekwon, Ab Soul, and Earl Sweatshirt, respectively). As a final shot of gravitas, Scarface drops a verse on \\\"Broken.\\\" It's a deserved blessing from one of hip-hop's finest MCs to one of its most unlikely but successful Rocking a compelling mix of thugged-out street tales and sensitive/intellectual musings, he was briefly signed to Interscope and has since dropped a gang of impressive mixtapes (such as \u003ci\u003eThe Miseducation of Freddie Gibbs\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003eFull Metal Jackit\u003c/i\u003e). He's also collaborated on EPs with Madlib and Statik Selektah; another one with Ski Beatz is in the works. On \u003ci\u003eCold Day in Hell\u003c/i\u003e, he joins forces with a diverse crew of fellow emcees, including big names like Young Jeezy (\\\"Twos and Fews\\\"), 2 Chainz (\\\"Neighborhood Hoez\\\"), and Memphis O.G. Juicy J (\\\"Str8 Slammin'\\\"), as well as more obscure cats like B.J. the Chicago Kid, Alley Boy, and Polyester. The production is fantastic and surprisingly varied, with tons of soulful samples and more straightforward synth bangers. Vocally, Gibbs combines the raspiness of a young Ja Rule crossed with the deep thinking of Scarface or Big K.R.I.T.         <div class="product-page-header__notes typography-caption">
            <div class="truncated-content-in-modal">
<!---->
    <div class="truncated-content-container" style="height: undefined">
        <span class="line-clamp " data-clamp>
    <p dir="false" data-test-bidi><span
                    data-test-truncated-content-inline-title
                    class="truncated-content-in-modal__inline-title"
                >Editors’ Notes</span>
                <i>2wice</i> marks Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs’ first offering since being acquitted of sexual assault in 2016—a charge that could’ve landed him in jail for 10 years. The material here is accordingly reflective, tempering Gibbs’ street operas with musings on potential (“Crushed Glass”), parenting (“Homesick”), and growing up (“Alexys”). As always, Gibbs’ raps are low-key but expertly constructed, the work of a guy confident enough to know he doesn’t need to show off.</p>
</span>

<!---->    </div>
</div>


        </div>
</div>

                        TIME

2014 Madlib Invazion\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"826080165\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"At first glance, the pairing of producer Madlib and rapper Freddie Gibbs seems unlikely. The former is the ultimate crate-digger, known as much for his reclusive tendencies as his endless collection of obscure soul, jazz, rock, and other musical ephemera; the latter is a street-hardened former dealer who rhymes about the perils of the dope game. But they say opposites attract, and in this case their two aesthetics complement one another. Gibbs is a nimble, gifted rapper, his syllables quick-stepping around Madlib's many twists and turns, from the grainy '70s soul-funk of \\\"Scarface\\\" to the half-time disco of \\\"Harold's\\\" to the hazy West Coast G-funk of \\\"Thuggin.\\\" The duo's credentials are strong enough to pull some of hip-hop's finest into their orbit: oddball Danny Brown contributes a verse to the squirming \\\"High,\\\" while the crews from The Wu-Tang Clan, Top Dog Entertainment, and Odd Future are all represented (via cameos from Raekwon, Ab Soul, and Earl Sweatshirt, respectively). As a final shot of gravitas, Scarface drops a verse on \\\"Broken.\\\" It's a deserved blessing from one of hip-hop's finest MCs to one of its most unlikely but successful If 2014’s \u003ci\u003ePiñata\u003c/i\u003e proved that the pairing—offbeat producer, no-frills street rapper—sounded better and more natural than it looked on paper, \u003ci\u003eBandana\u003c/i\u003e proves \u003ci\u003ePiñata\u003c/i\u003e wasn’t a fluke. The common ground is approachability: Even at their most cinematic (the noisy soul of “Flat Tummy Tea,” the horror-movie trap of “Half Manne Half Cocaine”), Madlib’s beats remain funny, strange, decidedly at human scale, while Gibbs prefers to keep things so real he barely uses metaphor. wary of talking himself up—he’s more show than tell. But between 2019’s Madlib collaboration (\u003ci\u003eBandana\u003c/i\u003e) and the Alchemist-led \u003ci\u003eAlfredo\u003c/i\u003e, what wasn’t clear 10 years ago is crystal now: Gibbs is in his own class. The wild, shape-shifting flow of “God Is Perfect,” the chilling lament of “Skinny Suge” (“Man, my uncle died off a overdose/And the fucked-up part of that is I know I supplied the n***a that sold it”), a mind that flickers with street violence and half-remembered Arabic, and beats that don’t bang so much as twinkle, glide, and go up like smoke. \u003ci\u003eAlfredo\u003c/i\u003e is seamless, seductive, but effortless, the work of two guys who don’t run to catch planes. On “Something to Rap About,” Gibbs claims, “God made me sell crack so I had something to rap about.” But the way he flows now, you get the sense he would’ve found his way to the mic one way or the Two years later he scored a deal with Interscope, but was dropped before his album was released. Undaunted, he continued to record independently and flood the streets with a gang of new material, most notably \u003ci\u003eThe Miseducation of Freddie Gibbs\u003c/i\u003e and \u003ci\u003emidwestgangstaboxframecadillacmuzik\u003c/i\u003e. Over the last few years, he's collaborated with artists from commercial staples like Young Jeezy and DJ Drama to underground icons Madlib and Statik Selektah. And his reputation has kept growing. With a gruff yet smooth flow and vivid storytelling verses, he rhymes mostly about various hood scenarios, sharing mic time with guests like Z-Ro, Curren$y, Krayzie Bone, Jadakiss, Dom Kennedy, SpaceGistPurp, and more. While this isn't his greatest album, there's no shortage of epic music. Juicy J (\\\"Str8 Slammin'\\\"), as well as more obscure cats like B.J. the Chicago Kid, Alley Boy, and Polyester. The production is fantastic and surprisingly varied, with tons of soulful samples and more straightforward synth bangers. Vocally, Gibbs combines the raspiness of a young Ja Rule crossed with the deep thinking of Scarface or Big K.R.I.T.
